author: wsjcom
title: Keep Football Exciting While Making It Safer
text: Dr. Paul S. Auerbach (“How to Save Football Players’ Brains,” op-ed, Jan. 20) is quite correct that football, particularly the NFL variety, is “a violent collision sport that causes the majority of traumatic brain injuries in athletes.” Lest we not delude ourselves, neither the NFL’s “concussion protocol” nor the advent of innovative and presumably safer helmets have done much to prevent brain damage. The primary mechanism of collision injury is the torque force of impact. That action creates rotational force which propels delicate brain tissue against the rigidity of the bone-hard skull.
